subject: Cybersecurity
title: WEP to WPA3: The Evolution of Wi-Fi Security
description: A micro-lesson that makes WEP to WPA3: The Evolution of Wi-Fi Security usable.

hook.text: Early Wi-Fi encryption was so weak that a teenager with a laptop could crack it in 60 seconds.

buildup.text: WEP (1997) was the first Wi-Fi security protocol. It used a static 40-bit key that was trivially breakable.

discovery.text: WPA (2003) added TKIP with per-packet keys. WPA2 (2004) brought AES encryption. WPA3 (2018) added forward secrecy.

twist.text: Despite WPA3's availability, millions of devices still use WPA2 or even WEP. Legacy hardware holds back.

climax.text: Wi-Fi security evolved through failure. Each broken protocol taught us what the next one needed.

punchline.text: 60 seconds to crack WEP. Wi-Fi security learned the hard way.

quiz.question: Why was WEP considered insecure?
options: It used a static 40-bit key that was trivially breakable
